Bayes' theorem: special case

This result is obtained by supposing that the sample space \(S\) is partitioned by event \(A\) and its complement \(A'\) to give:\[\mathbb{P}(A|B) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(B|A)\times\mathbb{P}(A)}{\mathbb{P}(B|A)\times\mathbb{P}(A) + \mathbb{P}(B|A')\times\mathbb{P}(A')}\]

Example

At a certain university, let \(M\) denote the set of students assigned male at birth, and let \(F\) denote the set of students assigned female at birth. \(4\%\) of students in \(M\) are over \(6\) feet tall and \(1\%\) of students in \(F\) are over \(6\) feet tall. The total student population is divided between these two sets. in the ratio \(3:2\) with \(F\) being the larger set. If a student is selected at random from among all those over six feet tall, what is the probability that the student is in \(F\)?

Solution

Note that \(M\) and \(F\) partition the sample space of students.

Let \(T=\{\text{Student is over 6 feet tall}\}\).

We know that \(\mathbb{P}(M) = 2/5\), \(\mathbb{P}(F) = 3/5\), \(\mathbb{P}(T|M) = 4/100\) and \(\mathbb{P}(T|F) = 1/100\).

We require \(\mathbb{P}(F|T)\). Using Bayes’ theorem we have:\[\begin{aligned}\mathbb{P}(F|T) &= \frac{\mathbb{P}(T|F)\mathbb{P}(F)}{\mathbb{P}(T|F)\mathbb{P}(F)+\mathbb{P}(T|M)\mathbb{P}(M)} \\ &= \frac{(1/100)(3/5)}{(1/100)(3/5) + (4/100)(2/5)} \\ &= \frac{3}{11}.\end{aligned}\]

Example

A factory production line is manufacturing bolts using three machines, \(1\), \(2\) and \(3\). Of the total output, machine \(1\) is responsible for \(25\%\), machine \(2\) for \(35\%\) and machine \(3\) for the rest. It is known from previous experience with the machines that \(5\%\) of the output from machine \(1\) is defective, \(4\%\) from machine \(2\) and \(2\%\) from machine \(3\). A bolt is chosen at random from the production line and found to be defective. What is the probability that it came from:

  1. machine \(1\)?
  2. machine \(2\)?
  3. machine \(3\)?

Solution

Let\[\begin{aligned}D &=\{\text{bolt is defective}\},\\ A &=\{\text{bolt is from machine }1\},\\ B &=\{\text{bolt is from machine }2\},\\ C &=\{\text{bolt is from machine }3\}.\end{aligned}\]

We know that \(\mathbb{P}(A) = 0.25\), \(\mathbb{P}(B) = 0.35\) and \(\mathbb{P}(C) = 0.4\). Also\[\mathbb{P}(D|A) = 0.05,\quad\mathbb{P}(D|B) = 0.04,\quad\mathbb{P}(D|C) = 0.02.\]

A statement of Bayes’ theorem for three events \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) is\[\begin{aligned}\mathbb{P}(A|D) &= \frac{\mathbb{P}(D|A)\mathbb{P}(A)}{\mathbb{P}(D|A)\mathbb{P}(A) + \mathbb{P}(D|B)P(B) + \mathbb{P}(D|C)\mathbb{P}(C)}\\ &= \frac{0.05\times0.25}{0.05\times0.25+0.04\times0.35+0.02\times0.4}\\ &= 0.362.\end{aligned}\]

Similarly\[\begin{aligned}\mathbb{P}(B|D) &= \frac{0.04\times0.35}{0.05\times0.25+0.04\times0.35+0.02\times0.4}\\ &= 0.406 \\ \mathbb{P}(C|D) &= \frac{0.02\times0.4}{0.05\times0.25+0.04\times0.35+0.02\times0.4}\\ &= 0.232.\end{aligned}\]
